parts: Give me a minimalist but robust latex template that I can use for lecture notes on a given topic in Mathematics that I am teaching. Good spacing, ample margins are also important. I wish also to use multiple latex files to avoid cramming a large chunk of text into a single file.

thoughts.content: I think I should provide a LaTeX template with instructions on splitting it into multiple files. For this, I'll create a code file with a proper structure, like `main.tex`, `preamble.tex`, and `content/lecture01.tex`. The template should use `article` or `scrartcl` for good margins, and include useful packages like `amsmath`, `tikz-cd`, `hyperref`, and others, with a sample Makefile. I'll make sure it’s easy for the user to iterate on.

I’ll use the `subfiles` package to handle multiple files with standalone compilation. The project will include `main.tex`, `preamble.tex`, `frontmatter/titlepage.tex`, and lecture files like `lecture01.tex`, all in a clear structure. We’ll use `scrartcl` for great spacing, KOMA options for layout, and detailed instructions on compiling and adding new lectures. I’ll keep it concise, with minimal but functional setup, making sure the user gets a clean document they can iterate on.

I’ll use the "code/other" format to provide the LaTeX code, as it's not listed as a supported type. The instructions suggest using fenced code blocks, so I’ll structure the canvas content that way, using separate sections to label files and their respective code. I’ll confirm briefly in the chat and avoid repeating content directly.

I’ll provide clear and concise instructions on how to compile the LaTeX document, along with preferences for XeLaTeX vs pdfLaTeX. For the font choices, I’ll keep it simple, using `fontspec` for XeLaTeX/LuaLaTeX if needed, and stick with pdfLaTeX for a more robust setup. I’ll also add common theorem environments, `microtype`, and good spacing with `geometry`, `parskip`, and `scrlayer-scrpage`. The structure will include main, preamble, and title page files.

canvas.title: Mathematics Lecture Notes – Minimalist La Te X Template (multi-file)

parts:
I’ve dropped a clean, multi-file LaTeX setup in the canvas. It gives you wide, readable margins, sane spacing, proper theorem environments, headers/footers, and a subfiles-based structure so each lecture compiles on its own.

Quick start:

1) Create the folders shown at the bottom of the canvas file, then save each block to its filename.  
2) Compile the whole set via `pdflatex main.tex` (or `xelatex main.tex` if you uncomment the `fontspec` bits).  
3) Work per-lecture by opening `lectures/lecture01.tex` (or `lecture02.tex`) and compiling directly—fast iterations without rebuilding everything.  
4) Add more lectures by copying `lecture02.tex` and listing them in `main.tex` with `\subfile{lectures/your_lecture}`.

Tweaks you might want:
- Prefer `\include/\includeonly` over `subfiles` if you’re building massive PDFs and want LaTeX’s page-level caching.  
- Switch fonts: with XeLaTeX/LuaLaTeX, uncomment the `fontspec` section and pick your system serif and sans.  
- Bibliography: uncomment the `biblatex` lines, add `bib/references.bib`, and compile with `biber`.

Want me to tailor it for a specific course (e.g., metric geometry, measure theory) or switch to `book`/`scrreprt` with chaptering?
